latin.enphrase: They dragged themselves from the sea and entrusted themselves to powerful Caesar.
latin.fnphrase: Se ex mari traxerunt seque Caesari potenti commiserunt.

latin.enphrase: Hunger is the best cook.
latin.fnphrase: Fames est optimus coquus.

latin.enphrase: Caesar was not able to join his troops with the troops of the king.
latin.fnphrase: Caesar non poterat suas copias cum copiis regis iungere.

latin.enphrase: May he love tomorrow who has never loved before.
latin.fnphrase: Cras amet qui numquam amavit.

latin.enphrase: Cicero used to keep the names of all the citizens in his sharp memory.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero nomina omnium civium acri memoria tenebat.

latin.enphrase: A word to a wise person is sufficient.
latin.fnphrase: Dictum sapienti sat est.

latin.enphrase: The Cyclops was a horrible, hideous, and huge monster.
latin.fnphrase: Cyclops erat monstrum horrendum, informe, ingens.

latin.enphrase: It is difficult to give up a long love suddenly.
latin.fnphrase: Difficile est longum subito deponere amorem.

latin.enphrase: "A woman is always a fickle and changeable thing." - Vergil's Aeneid
latin.fnphrase: "Varium et mutabile semper femina." - Aenedia Vergilii

latin.enphrase: Happy is the person who has been able to learn the causes of things.
latin.fnphrase: Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas.

latin.enphrase: The poetic art is not to say everything.
latin.fnphrase: Ars poetica est non omnia dicere.

latin.enphrase: The drop hollows out the stone, not with force but by falling often.
latin.fnphrase: Gutta cavat lapidem, non vi sed saepe cadendo.

latin.enphrase: Nothing is fortunate in every part.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil est ab omni parte beatum.

latin.enphrase: Fire tests gold; adversity tests strong men.
latin.fnphrase: Ignis aurum probat, miseria fortes viros.

latin.enphrase: The philosopher's book helps people with its wise counsel.
latin.fnphrase: Liber philosophi homines prudenti consilio adiuvat.

latin.enphrase: He seems to me to be equal to a god.
latin.fnphrase: llle mi par esse deo videtur.

latin.enphrase: The mother of all good arts is wisdom.
latin.fnphrase: Mater omnium bonarum artium sapientia est.

latin.translation: to excuse, to make an excuse for
latin.enphrase: Ignorance of the law excuses no one.
latin.fnphrase: Ignorantia iuris neminem excusat.

latin.enphrase: He lives and will live through the memory of all ages.
latin.fnphrase: Vivit et vivet per omnium saeculorum memoriam.

latin.enphrase: Fortune provides friends; poverty tests them.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna amicos parat, inopia amicos probat.

latin.enphrase: We are beginning to understand the truth, which helps all people.
latin.fnphrase: Incipimus veritatem intellegere, quae homines adiuvat.

latin.enphrase: It is better to bend than to break.
latin.fnphrase: Melius est flecti quam frangi.

latin.enphrase: Necessity knows no law.
latin.fnphrase: Necessitas non habet legem.

latin.enphrase: Dionysius sailed to Sicily.
latin.fnphrase: Dionysius ad Siciliam navigavit.

latin.translation: to be a slave, to serve
latin.enphrase: No one is free who is a slave to his body.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo liber est qui corpori servit.

latin.enphrase: Many citizens do not see those dangers which threaten them.
latin.fnphrase: Multi cives ea pericula quae imminent non vident.

latin.enphrase: The man who is constantly in fear is condemned every day.
latin.fnphrase: Cotidie damnatur qui semper timet.

latin.enphrase: He does not lack who does not desire.
latin.fnphrase: Non caret is qui non desiderat.

latin.enphrase: The opposite is cured with the opposite.
latin.fnphrase: Contraria contrariis curantur.

latin.enphrase: Fortune is fickle.
latin.fnphrase: Levis est fortuna.

latin.enphrase: War is sweet for those who are unexperienced in it.
latin.fnphrase: Dulce bellum inexpertis.

latin.enphrase: Fortune makes him stupid whom it loves too much.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna eum stultum facit quem nimium amat.

latin.enphrase: A physician treats, nature cures.
latin.fnphrase: Medicus curat, natura sanat.

latin.enphrase: Insincerity destroys truth, without which the name of friendship cannot be strong.
latin.fnphrase: Simulatio delet veritatem sine qua nomen amicitiae valere non potest.

latin.translation: to trust, to confide, to rely on
latin.enphrase: A mouse does not rely on just one hole.
latin.fnphrase: Mus uni non fidit antro.

latin.enphrase: Avoid the crowd!
latin.fnphrase: Turbam vita!

latin.enphrase: Nature does nothing in vain.
latin.fnphrase: Natura nihil fit frustra.

latin.enphrase: The book you recite is mine; but when you recite it badly it begins to be yours.
latin.fnphrase: Liber quem recitas meus est; sed cum male eum recitas, incipit esse tuus.

latin.enphrase: Common danger brings forth harmony.
latin.fnphrase: Commune periculum concordiam parit.

latin.enphrase: Caesar is warned by these omens.
latin.fnphrase: Caesar his prodigiis admonetur.

latin.enphrase: Repetition is the mother of memory.
latin.fnphrase: Repetitio est mater memoriae.

latin.enphrase: Repetition is the mother of studies.
latin.fnphrase: Repetitio est mater studiorum.

latin.enphrase: There is nothing more foolish than a foolish laugh.
latin.fnphrase: Risu inepto res ineptior nulla est.

latin.enphrase: The city was being destroyed by flames.
latin.fnphrase: Urbs flammis delebatur.

latin.enphrase: True joy is a serious thing.
latin.fnphrase: Verum gaudium est res severa.

latin.enphrase: The happy memory of sweet friendships will never be destroyed.
latin.fnphrase: Beata memoria amicitiarum dulcium numquam delebitur.

latin.enphrase: One who sleeps does not sin.
latin.fnphrase: Qui dormit non peccat.

latin.enphrase: The plans of the king were destroyed by a long and difficult war.
latin.fnphrase: Consilia regis bello longo et difficili delebantur.

latin.enphrase: A poet is born, not made.
latin.fnphrase: Poeta nascitur, non fit.

latin.enphrase: Even brave men are frightened by sudden dangers.
latin.fnphrase: Etiam fortes viri subitis periculis terrentur.

latin.enphrase: There is no one like him.
latin.fnphrase: Non est ei similis.

latin.enphrase: Cicero's plans are clear to us.
latin.fnphrase: Consilia Ciceronis sunt clara nobis.

latin.enphrase: It is pleasant to do nothing.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil agere delectat.

latin.enphrase: It is right to be taught by one's enemy.
latin.fnphrase: Fas est ab hoste doceri.

latin.enphrase: Music soothes the savage beast.
latin.fnphrase: Musica delenit bestiam feram.

latin.enphrase: All things change; all things flow; what we have been or are, tomorrow we will not be.
latin.fnphrase: Omnia mutantur; omnia fluunt; quod fuimus aut sumus, cras non erimus.

latin.enphrase: He is greatest in the smallest things.
latin.fnphrase: Maximus in minimis.

latin.enphrase: Love cannot be mixed with fear.
latin.fnphrase: Amor misceri cum timore non potest.

latin.enphrase: Fame comes too late to the dead.
latin.fnphrase: Cineri gloria sera venit.

latin.enphrase: Never, in fact, will rashness be united with wisdom.
latin.fnphrase: Numquam enim temeritas cum sapientia commiscetur.

latin.enphrase: Love the intellect intensely.
latin.fnphrase: Intellectum valde ama.

latin.enphrase: Those proofs appeared certain.
latin.fnphrase: Illa argumenta visa sunt certa.

latin.translation: to be silent, to be still
latin.enphrase: In time of war laws are silent.
latin.fnphrase: Inter arma silent leges.

latin.enphrase: Good citizens are those who hold the benefits of their country in their memory.
latin.fnphrase: Boni cives sunt ei qui beneficia patriae memoria tenent.

latin.enphrase: This man has sold his country for gold.
latin.fnphrase: Vendidit hic auro patriam.

latin.enphrase: The messenger ran from the army to the senate.
latin.fnphrase: Nuntius cucurrit ab exercitu ad senatum.

latin.enphrase: Knowledge itself is power.
latin.fnphrase: Ipsa scientia potestas est.

latin.enphrase: In our age few things are prepared by hand.
latin.fnphrase: Nostra aetate pauca manu parantur.

latin.enphrase: There is, to be sure, no evil without something good.
latin.fnphrase: Malum quidem nullum est sine aliquo bono.

latin.enphrase: When his verses were read the poet was praised.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi versus lecti sunt, poeta laudatus est.

latin.enphrase: The workmanship surpassed the subject matter.
latin.fnphrase: Opus superabat materiam.

latin.enphrase: The horns of stags defend them from dangers.
latin.fnphrase: Cornua cervum a periculis defendunt.

latin.enphrase: Doctors cure the more serious diseases with harsh remedies.
latin.fnphrase: Medici graviores morbos asperis remediis curant.

latin.enphrase: Oedipus deprived himself of his eyes.
latin.fnphrase: Oedipus oculis se privavit.

latin.enphrase: As a true translator you will take care not to translate word for word.
latin.fnphrase: Nec verbum verbo curabis reddere fidus interpres.

latin.enphrase: In the Persian War, Themistocles freed Greece from slavery.
latin.fnphrase: Bello Persico Themistocles Graeciam servitute liberavit.

latin.enphrase: No one ever became thoroughly bad all at once.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo repente fuit turpissimus.

latin.enphrase: Cicero used to pronounce many words in one breath.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero multa verba uno spiritu pronuntiabat.

latin.enphrase: Nothing is certain for man.
latin.fnphrase: Nil homini certum est.

latin.enphrase: That man lacks common feeling.
latin.fnphrase: Iste communi sensu caret.

latin.enphrase: There is no greed without penalty.
latin.fnphrase: Nulla avarita sine poena est.

latin.enphrase: Old age deprives us of all pleasures.
latin.fnphrase: Senectus nos privat omnibus voluptatibus.

latin.enphrase: Nothing is now said that hasn't been said before.
latin.fnphrase: Nullum est iam dictum quod non dictum sit prius.

latin.enphrase: No accuser lacks guilt; we have all done wrong.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo accusator caret culpa; omnes peccavimus.

latin.enphrase: I do not live to eat, but eat to live.
latin.fnphrase: Non ut edam vivo, sed ut vivam edo.

latin.enphrase: No part of life is able to be free from duty.
latin.fnphrase: Nulla pars vitae vacare officio potest.

latin.enphrase: A single night awaits everyone.
latin.fnphrase: Omnes una manet nox.

latin.enphrase: The foremost virtue is to be free from fault.
latin.fnphrase: Prima virtus est vitio carere.

latin.enphrase: No one dances sober unless he's insane.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo saltat sobrius nisi insanit.

latin.enphrase: A man free from wickedness does not need javelins or a bow.
latin.fnphrase: Vir scelere vacuus non eget iaculis neque arcu.

latin.enphrase: Think before you leap.
latin.fnphrase: Cogita ante salis.

latin.enphrase: Great tumults were in the city at that time.
latin.fnphrase: Magni tumultus eo tempore in urbe erant.

latin.enphrase: Of two evils, the lesser must always be chosen.
latin.fnphrase: De duobus malis, minus est semper eligendum.

latin.enphrase: Excessive praise is often neither reliable nor great.
latin.fnphrase: Laus nimis saepe est neque certa neque magna.

latin.enphrase: The force of habit is great.
latin.fnphrase: Consuetudinis magna vis est.

latin.enphrase: Everyone was frightened by a new fear.
latin.fnphrase: Omnes metu novo territi sunt.

latin.enphrase: Against a lucky man, a god scarcely has power.
latin.fnphrase: Contra felicem vix deus vires habet.

latin.enphrase: What end of fear and slavery can be seen in that state?
latin.fnphrase: Qui finis metus atque servitutis in ea civitate potest videri?

latin.enphrase: The greatest respect is owed to a child.
latin.fnphrase: Maxima debetur puero reverentia.

latin.enphrase: Caesar will order this man to be lead away in chains.
latin.fnphrase: Caesar iubebit hunc in vincula duci.

latin.enphrase: No one is without fault.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo sine vitio est.

latin.enphrase: There will also be other wars and great Achilles will be sent to Troy a second time.
latin.fnphrase: Erunt etiam altera bella atque iterum ad Troiam magnus mittetur Achilles.

latin.enphrase: No one is able to flee from death or love.
latin.fnphrase: Nec mortem effugere quisquam nec amorem potest.

latin.enphrase: Friendship is shut out in no place; it is never out of season.
latin.fnphrase: Amicitia nullo loco excluditur; numquam intempestiva est.

latin.enphrase: No man is more deaf than he who will not hear.
latin.fnphrase: Nemo surdior est quam is qui non audiet.

latin.enphrase: The public wishes to be deceived.
latin.fnphrase: Vulgus vult decipi.

latin.enphrase: Not everything that is permitted is honorable.
latin.fnphrase: Non omne quod licet honestum est.

latin.enphrase: Where there is a tyrant, there clearly is no republic.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi tyrannus est, ibi plane est nulla res publica.

latin.enphrase: There is no great genius without a mixture of madness.
latin.fnphrase: Nullum magnum ingenium est sine mixtura dementiae.

latin.enphrase: There were once, in this republic, men of great virtue.
latin.fnphrase: Fuerunt quondam in hac re publica viri magnae virtutis.

latin.enphrase: Death makes all things equal.
latin.fnphrase: Omnia mors aequat.

latin.enphrase: We wish this republic to be safe.
latin.fnphrase: Hanc rem publicam salvam esse volumus.

latin.enphrase: The beginnings of all things are small.
latin.fnphrase: Omnium rerum principia parva sunt.

latin.enphrase: Greek sailors, seeing the Romans, trembled.
latin.fnphrase: Graeci nautae, videntes Romanos, tremuerunt.

latin.translation: to call out, to rouse, to kindle
latin.enphrase: The small spark often kindles a large flame.
latin.fnphrase: Parva scintilla saepe magnam flamam excitat.

latin.enphrase: Tantalus, being thirsty, was wishing to touch rivers fleeing from his lips.
latin.fnphrase: Tantalus sitiens flumina a labris fugientia tangere cupiebat.

latin.enphrase: Poverty is the inventor of all the arts.
latin.fnphrase: Paupertas omnium artium repertrix est.

latin.enphrase: The signs of future things are shown by the gods.
latin.fnphrase: Signa rerum futurarum a dis ostenduntur.

latin.enphrase: All things yield to money.
latin.fnphrase: Pecuniae oboediunt omnia.

latin.enphrase: Reading Plato, I always weep over the death of Socrates.
latin.fnphrase: Legens Platonem morti Socratis semper illacrimo.

latin.translation: to not know, to be ignorant
latin.enphrase: What they don't know won't kill them.
latin.fnphrase: Quod nesciunt eos non interficiet.

latin.enphrase: The memory of a life well-lived is pleasant.
latin.fnphrase: Memoria vitae bene actae iucunda est.

latin.enphrase: He who has much desires more.
latin.fnphrase: Qui multum habet plus cupit.

latin.enphrase: Since Caesar holds the power, I fear the outcome.
latin.fnphrase: Caesare imperium tenente eventum timeo.

latin.enphrase: He who is not prepared today will be less so tomorrow.
latin.fnphrase: Qui non est hodie cras minus aptus erit.

latin.enphrase: Since Caesar is the commander, we shall fear nothing.
latin.fnphrase: Caesare duce nihil timebimus.

latin.enphrase: He who fears every ambush falls into none.
latin.fnphrase: Qui omnes insidias timet in nullas incidit.

latin.enphrase: On that day, Cicero returned from exile.
latin.fnphrase: Eo die Cicero de exsilio revenit.

latin.enphrase: Whom the gods love dies young.
latin.fnphrase: Quem di diligunt, adolescens moritur.

latin.enphrase: After Asia had been conquered, the Roman general sent many slaves to Italy.
latin.fnphrase: Asia victa, dux Romanus servos multos in Italiam misit.

latin.enphrase: What is food to some is poison to others.
latin.fnphrase: Quod cibus est aliis, aliis est venenum.

latin.enphrase: All these wounds of war must now be healed by you.
latin.fnphrase: Haec omnia vulnera belli tibi nunc sananda sunt.

latin.enphrase: With the tyrant Tarquinius having been expelled, I do not fear violent death.
latin.fnphrase: Tarquinio tyranno expulso mortem violentam non timeo.

latin.enphrase: He who wishes to give little shouldn't ask for much.
latin.fnphrase: Qui vult dare parva non debet magna rogare.

latin.enphrase: With the king expelled, the hope and faith of free men will hold the republic together.
latin.fnphrase: Rege expulso spes fidesque virorum liberorum rem publicam continebunt.

latin.enphrase: Often the prickly thorn produces tender roses.
latin.fnphrase: Saepe creat molles aspera spina rosas.

latin.enphrase: Caesar accepted supreme power.
latin.fnphrase: Caesar imperium accepit.

latin.enphrase: If you are wise, you should be a bee.
latin.fnphrase: Si sapis, sis apis.

latin.enphrase: With the enemy approaching, the senate announced to Cincinnatus that he had been made dictator.
latin.fnphrase: Hostibus appropinquantibus senatus Cincinnato nuntiavit eum factum esse dictatorem.

latin.enphrase: He that is silent is thought to consent.
latin.fnphrase: Qui tacet consentire videtur.

latin.enphrase: Stranger, tell them at Sparta that you saw us lying here faithful to our country.
latin.fnphrase: Dic, hospes, Spartae te nos hic iacentes vidisse patriae fideles.

latin.enphrase: Cicero believes that the immortal gods sowed souls into human bodies.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero credit deos immortales sparisse animos in corpora humana.

latin.enphrase: Where there is doubt, there is freedom.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi dubium ibi libertas.

latin.enphrase: Where there's smoke, there's fire.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi fumus, ibi ignis.

latin.enphrase: Though it may be great, the wrath of the gods is certainly slow.
latin.fnphrase: Ut sit magna, tamen certe lenta ira deorum est.

latin.enphrase: The young man hopes that he will live a long time.
latin.fnphrase: Adulescens sperat se diu victurum esse.

latin.enphrase: The old man can say that he has lived a long time.
latin.fnphrase: Senex potest dicere se diu vixisse.

latin.enphrase: Vanity of vanities, all is vanity.
latin.fnphrase: Vanitas vanitatum, omnis vanitas.

latin.enphrase: Truth never perishes.
latin.fnphrase: Veritas numquam perit.

latin.enphrase: His life was too short.
latin.fnphrase: Vita eius erat brevior.

latin.enphrase: His life was very short.
latin.fnphrase: Vita eius erat brevissima.

latin.enphrase: The truth will set you free.
latin.fnphrase: Veritas vos liberabit.

latin.enphrase: Truth hates delay.
latin.fnphrase: Veritas odit moras.

latin.enphrase: Certain leaders once desired to suppress free men.
latin.fnphrase: Quidam duces quondam liberos viros opprimere cupiebant.

latin.enphrase: It gains strength as it goes.
latin.fnphrase: Vires acquirit eundo.

latin.enphrase: Old age is talkative.
latin.fnphrase: Senectus est loquax.

latin.enphrase: One must avoid that wicked temptress, Laziness.
latin.fnphrase: Vitanda est improba siren desidia.

latin.enphrase: Some poems are good; more are bad.
latin.fnphrase: Quaedam carmina sunt bona; plura sunt mala.

latin.enphrase: The clothes make the man.
latin.fnphrase: Vestis virum reddit.

latin.enphrase: I hope that you spend this birthday as happily as possible.
latin.fnphrase: Spero te hunc natalem quam felicissimum acturum esse.

latin.enphrase: The love of wealth grows as the wealth itself grew.
latin.fnphrase: Crescit amor nummi, quantum ipsa pecunia crevit.

latin.enphrase: The greatest cure for anger is delay.
latin.fnphrase: Maximum remedium irae mora est.

latin.enphrase: Life itself is short, but is made longer by misfortunes.
latin.fnphrase: Brevis ipsa vita est sed malis fit longior.

latin.enphrase: He works so energetically in order to accomplish many things.
latin.fnphrase: Tam strenue laborat ut multa perficiat.

latin.enphrase: They condemn what they do not understand.
latin.fnphrase: Damnant quod non intellegunt.

latin.enphrase: Without delay, Cicero will warn the state about the plot of Catiline.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero sine mora civitatem de insidiis Catilinae monebit.

latin.enphrase: There is nothing new under the sun.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil sub sole novum.

latin.enphrase: How will we be able to remain in perpetual peace?
latin.fnphrase: Quomodo in perpetua pace remanere poterimus?

latin.enphrase: When will there be enough reason and courage in human beings?
latin.fnphrase: Ubi satis rationis animorumque in hominibus erit?

latin.enphrase: We shall never conquer danger without danger.
latin.fnphrase: Numquam periculum sine periculo vincemus.

latin.enphrase: The extraordinary beauty of Greek statues attracts the eyes of human beings.
latin.fnphrase: Eximia forma statuorum Graecorum oculos hominum convertit.

latin.enphrase: Among many cares, Horace is not able to write poems.
latin.fnphrase: Inter multas curas Horatio poemata scribere non potest.

latin.enphrase: We learn not for school, but for life.
latin.fnphrase: Non scholae sed vitae discimus.

latin.enphrase: Human beings, while teaching, learn.
latin.fnphrase: Homines, dum docent, discunt.

latin.enphrase: Reason will lead me, not fortune.
latin.fnphrase: Ratio me ducet, non fortuna.

latin.enphrase: Pompey will give a great amount of money to Caesar.
latin.fnphrase: Pompeius Caesari magnam copiam pecuniae dabit.

latin.enphrase: The customs of that tyrant of yours were evil.
latin.fnphrase: Mores istius tyranni erant mali.

latin.enphrase: Will the state be strong after this war?
latin.fnphrase: Valebitne civitas post hoc bellum?

latin.enphrase: This man will lead that woman into holy matrimony.
latin.fnphrase: Hic illam in sanctum matrimonium ducet.

latin.enphrase: You alone can save these men.
latin.fnphrase: Solus hos servare potes.

latin.enphrase: There is no place for those people in this land.
latin.fnphrase: Non est locus istis hominibus in hac terra.

latin.enphrase: Fate gives too much to many people, enough to no one.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna multis dat nimis, satis nulli.

latin.enphrase: Cicero wrote many things about old age.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero multa de senectute scripsit.

latin.enphrase: Ovid wrote many things about love.
latin.fnphrase: Ovidius multa de amore scripsit.

latin.enphrase: From the books of one man, we will learn about the nature of things.
latin.fnphrase: Ex libris unius de natura rerum discemus.

latin.enphrase: Flee the desire for money and glory!
latin.fnphrase: Cupiditatem pecuniae gloriaeque fugite.

latin.enphrase: I will do my duty.
latin.fnphrase: Officium meum faciam.

latin.enphrase: Always with great fear I begin to speak.
latin.fnphrase: Semper magno cum timore incipio dicere.

latin.enphrase: Seize, friends, the opportunity from the hour.
latin.fnphrase: Rapite, amici, occasionem de hora.

latin.enphrase: Time flees.
latin.fnphrase: Tempus fugit.

latin.enphrase: We find this virtue in this man alone.
latin.fnphrase: Hanc virtutem in hoc viro uno invenimus.

latin.enphrase: After a few hours, Caesar captured Asia Minor.
latin.fnphrase: Post paucas horas Caesar Asiam cepit.

latin.enphrase: In the beginning, Jupiter created the heaven and the earth.
latin.fnphrase: In principio Iupiter creavit caelum et terram.

latin.enphrase: The young man wishes to live a long time; the old man has lived a long time.
latin.fnphrase: Adulescens vult diu vivere; senex diu vixit.

latin.enphrase: You should always live mindful of death; the hour is fleeing.
latin.fnphrase: Semper debetis vivere memor mortis; hora fugit.

latin.enphrase: Where freedom has fallen, no one dares to speak freely.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi libertas cecidit, nemo libere dicere audet.

latin.enphrase: Hannibal was never able to capture Rome.
latin.fnphrase: Hannibalis Romam capere numquam potuit.

latin.enphrase: The gods send souls from heaven into the bodies of human beings.
latin.fnphrase: Di animos in corpora hominum e caelo mittunt.

latin.enphrase: That good man has lived well; that wicked man has lived better.
latin.fnphrase: Ille bonus bene vixit; ille malus melius vixit.

latin.enphrase: Mark Antony did not love the sister of Caesar Augustus.
latin.fnphrase: Marcus Antonius sororem Caesaris Augusti non dilexit.

latin.enphrase: From the fault of another human being, the wise man corrects his own.
latin.fnphrase: Ex vitio alterius hominis sapiens emendat suum.

latin.enphrase: Crassus accomplished many things with the power of money.
latin.fnphrase: Crassus vi pecuniae multa fecit.

latin.translation: to preserve, to keep, to save, to guard
latin.enphrase: Divine Pan guards the sheep and the masters of the sheep.
latin.fnphrase: Divinus Pan oves et magistros ovium servat.

latin.enphrase: So passes the glory of the world.
latin.fnphrase: Sic transit gloria mundi.

latin.enphrase: There are as many opinions as there are men.
latin.fnphrase: Quot homines, tot sententiae.

latin.enphrase: Withdraw into your very self.
latin.fnphrase: Recede in te ipsum.

latin.enphrase: Fortune is blind.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna est caeca.

latin.enphrase: Inhumanity is harmful in every age.
latin.fnphrase: Inhumanitas omni aetate molesta est.

latin.enphrase: The leaders themselves will save the liberty of their own citizens.
latin.fnphrase: Duces ipsi libertatem civium suorum servabunt.

latin.enphrase: The soul of Socrates was ignorant of evil arts.
latin.fnphrase: Animus Socratis erat ignarus artium malarum.

latin.enphrase: My name is Charlie Brown.
latin.fnphrase: Nomen est mihi Carolus Fuscus.

latin.enphrase: People gladly believe that which they wish.
latin.fnphrase: Libenter homines id quod volunt credunt.

latin.enphrase: From a pure spring, pure water flows.
latin.fnphrase: A fonte puro pura defluit aqua.

latin.enphrase: We are slaves of the laws so that we may be free.
latin.fnphrase: Legum servi sumus ut liberi esse possimus.

latin.enphrase: The soul itself nourishes itself.
latin.fnphrase: Animus se ipse alit.

latin.enphrase: The fatherland is the common parent of us all.
latin.fnphrase: Patria est communis omnium parens.

latin.enphrase: Often it is not even advantageous to know what will be.
latin.fnphrase: Saepe ne utile quidem est scire quid futurum sit.

latin.enphrase: It is foolish to fear what you cannot avoid.
latin.fnphrase: Stultum est timere quod vitare non potes.

latin.enphrase: A little ant can drag great things with his mouth.
latin.fnphrase: Parva formica magna ore trahere potest.

latin.enphrase: Delay and procrastination are hateful.
latin.fnphrase: Tarditas et procrastinatio odiosa est.

latin.translation: to carry, to carry on, to accomplish
latin.enphrase: We accomplish great things not with strength and swiftness of our bodies, but with wisdom and skill.
latin.fnphrase: Non viribus et celeritate corporum magna gerimus, sed sapientia et arte.

latin.enphrase: Remember to keep a level head in difficult times.
latin.fnphrase: Aequam memento rebus in arduis servare mentem.

latin.enphrase: It is sweet and glorious to die for one's country, but it is sweeter to live for one's country.
latin.fnphrase: Dulce et decorum est pro patria mori, sed dulcius pro patria vivere.

latin.enphrase: Alas, the fleeing years slip away.
latin.fnphrase: Eheu, fugaces labuntur anni.

latin.enphrase: It is difficult to retain what you may have learned unless you should practice it.
latin.fnphrase: Difficile est tenere quae acceperis nisi excerceas.

latin.enphrase: Mortal deeds will perish.
latin.fnphrase: Mortalia facta peribunt.

latin.enphrase: Some laws are unwritten, but they are better established than all written ones.
latin.fnphrase: Quaedam non iura scripta sed omnibus scriptis certiora sunt.

latin.enphrase: As a true translator, you will take care not to translate word for word.
latin.fnphrase: Nec verbum verbo curabis reddere fidus interpres.

latin.enphrase: Dare to be wise!
latin.fnphrase: Sapere aude!

latin.enphrase: Constancy is the foundation of virtue.
latin.fnphrase: Basis virtutum constantia.

latin.enphrase: The greedy man is always in need.
latin.fnphrase: Semper avarus eget.

latin.enphrase: It is difficult not to write satire.
latin.fnphrase: Difficile est saturam non scribere.

latin.enphrase: Honesty is praised and neglected.
latin.fnphrase: Probitas laudatur et alget.

latin.enphrase: Better late than never.
latin.fnphrase: Potius sero quam numquam.

latin.enphrase: Those who run across the sea change the sky, not their soul.
latin.fnphrase: Caelum non animum mutant qui trans mare currunt.

latin.enphrase: They praise those good books, but they read those lousy ones.
latin.fnphrase: Laudant illos libros bonos, sed istos legunt.

latin.enphrase: The end justifies the means.
latin.fnphrase: Exitus acta probat.

latin.enphrase: Be patient and tough; one day this pain will be useful to you.
latin.fnphrase: Perfer et obdura; dolor hic tibi proderit olim.

latin.enphrase: Advise friends in secret; praise them openly.
latin.fnphrase: Secrete amicos admone; lauda palam.

latin.enphrase: The army of the Gauls ran through the fields to the sea.
latin.fnphrase: Exercitus Gallorum per rura ad mare cucurrit.

latin.enphrase: Diligence is a very great help even to a person of mediocre intelligence.
latin.fnphrase: Diligentia maximum etiam mediocris ingeni subsidium.

latin.enphrase: That man mourns truly, he who mourns without witnesses.
latin.fnphrase: Ille dolet vere, qui sine teste dolet.

latin.enphrase: While I breathe, I hope.
latin.fnphrase: Dum spiro, spero.

latin.enphrase: Nature, not rank, makes a good man.
latin.fnphrase: Bonum virum natura, non ordo, facit.

latin.enphrase: The appearances of things are deceptive.
latin.fnphrase: Fallaces sunt rerum species.

latin.enphrase: If you wish to be loved, love.
latin.fnphrase: Si vis amari, ama.

latin.enphrase: The cause of fear is ignorance.
latin.fnphrase: Timendi causa est nescire.

latin.enphrase: He conquers twice who conquers himself in victory.
latin.fnphrase: Bis vincit qui se vincit in victoria.

latin.enphrase: If glory comes after death, I am in no hurry.
latin.fnphrase: Si post fata venit gloria, non propero.

latin.enphrase: A plan that cannot be changed is bad.
latin.fnphrase: Malum est consilium quod mutari non potest.

latin.enphrase: Fortune helps the brave.
latin.fnphrase: Fortes fortuna adiuvat.

latin.enphrase: I am a human being: I think nothing human is alien to me.
latin.fnphrase: Homo sum: humani nihil a me alienum puto.

latin.enphrase: Divine nature gave us fields, human skill built our cities.
latin.fnphrase: Divina natura dedit agros, ars humana aedificavit urbes.

latin.enphrase: How well you live is important, not how long.
latin.fnphrase: Quam bene vivas refert, non quam diu.

latin.enphrase: Fools laugh at the Latin language.
latin.fnphrase: Rident stolidi verba Latina.

latin.enphrase: All wise men live happily, completely, and fortunately.
latin.fnphrase: Omnes sapientes feliciter, perfecte, fortunate vivunt.

latin.enphrase: You give twice if you give quickly.
latin.fnphrase: Bis das si cito das.

latin.enphrase: Philosophy is the art of life.
latin.fnphrase: Philosophia est ars vitae.

latin.enphrase: I love the girl who came from Italy.
latin.fnphrase: Amo puellam quae ex Italia venit.

latin.enphrase: Your glory and fame will always remain.
latin.fnphrase: Semper gloria et fama tua manebunt.

latin.enphrase: The general leads the Roman soldiers back to the city.
latin.fnphrase: Dux milites Romanos ad urbem reducit.

latin.enphrase: Hannibal came to the Alps, which no one had ever crossed before him with an army.
latin.fnphrase: Hannibal ad Alpes venit, quas nemo umquam ante eum cum exercitu transierat.

latin.enphrase: There is no place for such people in this land.
latin.fnphrase: Non est locus istis hominibus in hac terra.

latin.enphrase: Why do the powerful and immortal gods turn their eyes away from human matters?
latin.fnphrase: Cur dei potentes et immortales oculos a rebus humanis avertunt?

latin.enphrase: They do nothing without reason.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil sine ratione agunt.

latin.enphrase: The Romans called the first day after the sun, which is the first of the stars.
latin.fnphrase: Romani primum diem a sole appellaverunt, qui primus est stellarum.

latin.enphrase: The dangers of war are great.
latin.fnphrase: Pericula belli sunt magna.

latin.enphrase: No part of life can be free from duty.
latin.fnphrase: Nulla pars vitae vacare officio potest.

latin.enphrase: Our thoughts are free.
latin.fnphrase: Liberae sunt nostrae cogitationes.

latin.enphrase: When these things had been heard, he began to be afraid.
latin.fnphrase: His rebus auditis, coepit timere.

latin.enphrase: That woman understood all kinds of good arts.
latin.fnphrase: Illa femina omnia genera artium bonarum intellexit.

latin.enphrase: Leisure without literature is death.
latin.fnphrase: Otium sine litteris mors est.

latin.enphrase: Fortune is fickle: it quickly demands back what it gave.
latin.fnphrase: Levis est fortuna: id cito reposcit quod dedit.

latin.enphrase: What do these men think about you?
latin.fnphrase: Quid hi de te sentiunt?

latin.enphrase: Where will the state find men of good character?
latin.fnphrase: Ubi civitas viros bonorum morum inveniet?

latin.enphrase: No greed is without punishment.
latin.fnphrase: Nulla avaritia sine poena est.

latin.enphrase: Life is short; art long.
latin.fnphrase: Vita est brevis; ars longa.

latin.enphrase: Life is short; death long.
latin.fnphrase: Vita est brevis; mors longa.

latin.enphrase: Hail, emperor; we who are about to die salute you.
latin.fnphrase: Ave, imperator, morituri te salutamus.

latin.enphrase: Peace was dear to all the people.
latin.fnphrase: Pax fuit toti populo cara.

latin.enphrase: Wars are evil.
latin.fnphrase: Bella sunt mala.

latin.enphrase: Fortune loves great men.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna viros magnos amat.

latin.enphrase: They always praise the beauty of women.
latin.fnphrase: Formam feminarum semper laudant.

latin.enphrase: Not all people love the same things.
latin.fnphrase: Non omnes homines eadem amant.

latin.enphrase: What will you do?
latin.fnphrase: Quid tu facies?

latin.enphrase: We ought to avoid anger.
latin.fnphrase: Debemus iram vitare.

latin.enphrase: Nothing terrifies me.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil me terret.

latin.enphrase: Make haste slowly.
latin.fnphrase: Festina lente.

latin.enphrase: Mark and Horace are praising us.
latin.fnphrase: Marcus et Horatio nos laudant.

latin.enphrase: Life gives nothing to mortals without hard work.
latin.fnphrase: Nihil sine magno labore vita mortalibus dat.

latin.enphrase: The soldiers of Caesar often fought against the Gauls.
latin.fnphrase: Milites Caesaris saepe adversus Gallos pugnaverunt.

latin.enphrase: My friend is giving money to the girl.
latin.fnphrase: Amicus meus puellae pecuniam dat.

latin.enphrase: You should warn me if I make a mistake.
latin.fnphrase: Debetis me monere si erro.

latin.enphrase: A good thing is great wealth.
latin.fnphrase: Bona res est magna pecunia.

latin.enphrase: Nothing is swifter than rumor.
latin.fnphrase: Fama nihil est celerius.

latin.enphrase: The beauty of the Latin language is praised by many.
latin.fnphrase: Forma linguae Latinae a multis laudatur.

latin.enphrase: Antony went to Egypt, where he saw Cleopatra.
latin.fnphrase: Antonius ad Aegyptum iit, ubi Cleopatram vidit.

latin.enphrase: We see the son of the general running toward the enemy.
latin.fnphrase: Filium ducis currentem ad hostes videmus.

latin.enphrase: Julia was the daughter of Augustus.
latin.fnphrase: Iulia filia Augusti erat.

latin.enphrase: The foolish fear fate, but the wise endure it.
latin.fnphrase: Stulti fortunam timent, sapientes ferunt.

latin.enphrase: Cicero, a man of great fame, has many friends.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero, vir magnae famae, multos amicos habet.

latin.enphrase: Give me a gift of a thousand kisses.
latin.fnphrase: Da mihi donum basiorum mille.

latin.enphrase: Duty will always call free men.
latin.fnphrase: Officium liberos viros semper vocabit.

latin.enphrase: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
latin.fnphrase: Maximum remedium irae mora est.

latin.enphrase: The study of Roman history is difficult.
latin.fnphrase: Studium historiae Romanae difficile est.

latin.enphrase: Rome is my home country.
latin.fnphrase: Roma est patria mea.

latin.enphrase: The dangers of war are not small.
latin.fnphrase: Pericula belli non sunt parva.

latin.enphrase: Plato at that time was a teacher of philosophy.
latin.fnphrase: Plato tum magister philosophiae erat.

latin.translation: to be strong, to be well
latin.enphrase: If you and Octavian are well, Cicero and I are well.
latin.fnphrase: Si tu et Octavianus valetis, ego et Cicero valemus.

latin.enphrase: I will give myself completely to philosophy.
latin.fnphrase: Me totum philosophiae dabo.

latin.enphrase: No tyrant will be able to overcome the Roman people.
latin.fnphrase: Nullus tyrannus superare populum Romanum poterit.

latin.enphrase: Ancient books often contain words of wisdom.
latin.fnphrase: Libri antiqui verba sapientiae saepe continent.

latin.enphrase: Doubt is the beginning of wisdom.
latin.fnphrase: Dubium sapientiae initium.

latin.enphrase: I think, therefore I am.
latin.fnphrase: Cogito ergo sum.

latin.enphrase: Teachers often give cookies and gifts to small children.
latin.fnphrase: Magistri parvis pueris crustula et dona saepe dant.

latin.enphrase: The girl whom I love is beautiful.
latin.fnphrase: Puella quam amo pulchra est.

latin.enphrase: Fortune gives too much to many people, enough to no one.
latin.fnphrase: Fortuna multis hominibus dat nimis, satis nulli.

latin.enphrase: There is no crime without punishment.
latin.fnphrase: Nullum crimen sine poena.

latin.enphrase: The soul dwells in the eyes.
latin.fnphrase: In oculis animus habitat.

latin.enphrase: Under an evil tyrant we are not able to be free.
latin.fnphrase: Sub tyranno malo non possumus esse liberi.

latin.enphrase: Teachers use the books of great poets to teach their students.
latin.fnphrase: Libris magnorum poetarum magistri utuntur ad discipulos docendos.

latin.enphrase: Infinite is the number of foolish people.
latin.fnphrase: Infinitus est numerus stultorum.

latin.enphrase: The books of the Greeks and Romans were full of good thoughts.
latin.fnphrase: Libri Graecorum et Romanorum sententiarum bonarum pleni erant.

latin.enphrase: The people are strong in that place where the laws are strong.
latin.fnphrase: Ibi potest valere populus ubi leges valent.

latin.enphrase: I love you more than my own eyes.
latin.fnphrase: Magis te quam oculos amo meos.

latin.enphrase: Handsome men love pretty women.
latin.fnphrase: Belli viri bellas feminas amant.

latin.translation: to remain, to stay behind, to continue
latin.enphrase: Our glory and fame will always remain.
latin.fnphrase: Semper gloria et fama nostra remanebunt.

latin.enphrase: Where bees are, there is honey.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi apes, ibi mel.

latin.enphrase: Without the gods, the soul is not able to be good.
latin.fnphrase: Sine deis animus non potest bonus esse.

latin.enphrase: Marcus does not emulate evil men; he does not desire to be with them.
latin.fnphrase: Marcus non aemulatur viros malos; non desiderat esse cum eis

latin.enphrase: The glory of the good books of ancient poets will always remain.
latin.fnphrase: Gloria bonorum librorum antiquorum poetarum semper manebit.

latin.enphrase: We can tolerate neither our faults nor their remedies.
latin.fnphrase: Nec vitia nostra nec remedia tolerare possumus.

latin.enphrase: If the soul is weak, it will not be able to endure good fortune.
latin.fnphrase: Si animus infirmus est, non poterit bonam fortunam tolerare.

latin.enphrase: In our time flattery provides friends; the truth provides hatred.
latin.fnphrase: Hoc tempore obsequium amicos, veritas odium parit.

latin.enphrase: The tyrant will not be able to overcome the Roman people without money.
latin.fnphrase: Sine pecunia tyrannus superare populum Romanum non poterit.

latin.enphrase: It is not my fault.
latin.fnphrase: Non est mea culpa.

latin.enphrase: Roman poets were accustomed to learning the poems of Greek poets.
latin.fnphrase: Poetae Romani poemata poetarum Graecorum discere solebant.

latin.enphrase: Because of the care of Cicero our city will not be in continuous danger.
latin.fnphrase: Propter curam Ciceronis nostra civitas in perpetuo periculo non erit.

latin.enphrase: Agamemnon, king of the Greeks, led his forces to Troy.
latin.fnphrase: Agamemnon, rex Graecorum, copias ad Troiam duxit.

latin.translation: to surpass, to overcome, to conquer
latin.enphrase: Julius Caesar conquered Pompey the Great in the land of Greece.
latin.fnphrase: Iulius Caesar Pompeium Magnum in terra Graeca superavit.

latin.enphrase: Cicero will warn the state about the plot of Catiline without delay.
latin.fnphrase: Sine mora Cicero civitatem de insidiis Catalinae monebit.

latin.enphrase: The handsome man gave roses to his beautiful girlfriend.
latin.fnphrase: Vir pulcher amicae formosae rosas dedit.

latin.enphrase: That man dared to teach the virtue of work.
latin.fnphrase: Ille virtutem laboris docere ausus est.

latin.enphrase: A healthy mind in a healthy body.
latin.fnphrase: Mens sana in corpore sano.

latin.enphrase: Death is everything's final limit.
latin.fnphrase: Mors ultima linea rerum est.

latin.enphrase: The boy ran through the fields with his dog.
latin.fnphrase: Puer per agros cum cane cucurrit.

latin.enphrase: When catapults are outlawed, then only outlaws will have catapults.
latin.fnphrase: Cum catapultae proscriptae erunt tum soli proscripti catapultas habebunt.

latin.enphrase: They joined those cities with one road.
latin.fnphrase: Illas urbes una via iunxerunt.

latin.enphrase: Slight griefs talk, great ones are speechless.
latin.fnphrase: Curae leves loquuntur, ingentes stupent.

latin.enphrase: We preserved the freedom of these cities by using the arts of war.
latin.fnphrase: Libertatem harum urbium artibus belli conservavimus.

latin.enphrase: Punishment closely follows crime as its companion.
latin.fnphrase: Culpam poena premit comes.

latin.enphrase: The philosopher alone dares to deny that the gods exist.
latin.fnphrase: Solus philosophus negare deos esse audet.

latin.enphrase: Because of the storm, I expected death.
latin.fnphrase: Propter tempestatem mortem exspectavi.

latin.enphrase: Words fly away, but the written letter remains.
latin.fnphrase: Verba volant, littera scripta manet.

latin.translation: to hesitate, to waver, to doubt
latin.enphrase: They waver between war and peace.
latin.fnphrase: Inter bellum et pacem dubitant.

latin.enphrase: Where there is unity, there is victory.
latin.fnphrase: Ubi concordia ibi victoria.

latin.enphrase: Brave men used to live before our age.
latin.fnphrase: Fortes viri ante nostram aetatem vivebant.

latin.enphrase: The safety of the people is the supreme law.
latin.fnphrase: Salus populi suprema lex.

latin.enphrase: Certain philosophers removed all desires from themselves.
latin.fnphrase: Quidam philosophi omnes cupiditates ex se eiecerunt.

latin.enphrase: Only you can prevent forest fires.
latin.fnphrase: Solum potestis prohibere ignes silvarum.

latin.translation: to change, to alter, to exchange
latin.enphrase: The violence of war changed his life in a few hours.
latin.fnphrase: Vis belli vitam eius paucis horis mutavit.

latin.translation: to not wish, to be unwilling
latin.enphrase: I do not wish to be Caesar.
latin.fnphrase: Ego nolo Caesar esse.

latin.enphrase: They dragged themselves from the sea and entrusted themselves to powerful Caesar.
latin.fnphrase: Se ex mari traxerunt seque Caesari potenti commiserunt.

latin.enphrase: Hunger is the best cook.
latin.fnphrase: Fames est optimus coquus.

latin.enphrase: Caesar was not able to join his troops with the troops of the king.
latin.fnphrase: Caesar non poterat suas copias cum copiis regis iungere.

latin.enphrase: May he love tomorrow who has never loved before.
latin.fnphrase: Cras amet qui numquam amavit.

latin.enphrase: Cicero used to keep the names of all the citizens in his sharp memory.
latin.fnphrase: Cicero nomina omnium civium acri memoria tenebat.

latin.enphrase: A word to a wise person is sufficient.
latin.fnphrase: Dictum sapienti sat est.
